misconceptions.name: Implemented an average acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from three inputs (v0, v1, t) rather than a program that reads five integers and outputs the sum of the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that computes the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, use control structures to select only the even numbers, accumulate their sum, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t rather than five integers
Only three values are read from input instead of five
No loop or conditional logic to check for even numbers
Output message reports average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook/example problems or copying a solution for a different task instead of implementing the specified sum-of-evens program.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words. Identify the required inputs (five integers), the needed processing steps (loop over inputs, check evenness with n % 2 == 0, accumulate sum), and the exact required output format before you start coding.
related_concepts: Mapping problem descriptions to code structure (inputs, processing, output)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program, including variable names, prompt text, and formula, matches a standard acceleration example and does not contain any elements related to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The code solves an acceleration problem using three double inputs and prints an acceleration message instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misalignment with Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration using three double inputs (v0, v1, t), completely ignoring the assignment requirement to read five integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers. This code fails to meet all specified rubric tasks (input count/type, loop use, conditional check, accumulation).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem, indicating a misunderstanding of the required task or a file confusion.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read five separate integer inputs, utilizing a loop structure, employ conditional logic (if/modulus) to check for evenness, and use an accumulator variable to compute the total sum of even numbers.
symptoms: Prompts ask for 'v0, v1, and t'
Inputs are read as doubles, not integers
No loop structure used for input processing
Missing conditional logic for checking even numbers
Final output is 'The average acceleration is ...', not the required sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Major failure to adhere to assignment prompt specifications. Likely submitted code for a different exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure the submitted file addresses the specific requirements for reading 5 integers, using a loop structure, and implementing conditional summation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code demonstrably calculates acceleration, an entirely different task, evidenced by input prompts, variable names, and the calculation formula.

evidence.note: The class name suggests an irrelevant program.
Reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration, instead of reading 5 integers for summation.
Prints the result of an acceleration calculation instead of the required sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete misalignment with assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (acceleration calculator) instead of the sum of even numbers program. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment, submission of wrong file, or failure to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have worked on calculating acceleration from velocity and time rather than reading integers and filtering for even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, checking which ones are even (divisible by 2), summing only the even ones, and printing the result.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present
No modulo operation or even/odd checking
No accumulator for summing even numbers
Output is acceleration calculation, not sum of evens
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted the wrong program entirely, possibly from a different assignment or previous work.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with the correct problem. Write a program that: (1) creates a Scanner, (2) reads 5 integers in a loop, (3) checks if each is even with n % 2 == 0, (4) accumulates the sum, and (5) prints the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves a completely different problem with no overlap to the sum of evens requirement.

evidence.note: Entire program solves acceleration calculation, not sum of even numbers. Wrong assignment submitted.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for an unrelated physics formula instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for v0, v1, and t as doubles and reads only three values, instead of reading five integer values as required to compute the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles to compute average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly five integers from the user, which will then be processed to compute the sum of the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Prompt text refers to v0, v1, and t instead of five integers
Only three inputs are read
Inputs are read as doubles rather than integers
No mechanism exists to accept five separate integer values
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement or reuse of an unrelated template for average acceleration instead of implementing the specified task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the prompt to ask for five integers, use int variables, and ensure that you call nextInt() five times (possibly inside a loop) to read all five numbers.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard with Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements an average acceleration calculator and reads three doubles named v0, v1, and t, which does not match the requirement to read five integers.

evidence.note: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads only three double values, not five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any looping construct to process multiple user inputs, even though it needs to handle five separate numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can read each required value with separate nextDouble() calls and do not need a loop for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process a fixed number of repeated inputs (five integers), a loop should be used to read each number and apply the desired logic, making the code concise and scalable.
symptoms: No for, while, or do-while loop in the program
Each input is read with a standalone nextDouble() call
No repeated structure for processing five numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of recognition that repeated, similar operations should be implemented using a loop.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that runs five times, reading an integer in each iteration and processing it (e.g., checking if it is even and updating a running sum).
related_concepts: Iterating over a known number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no loop constructs and reads a fixed number of values manually, which conflicts directly with the rubric requirement for a loop.

evidence.note: Inputs are read with three separate calls and there is no loop anywhere in the file.

misconceptions.name: No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0), so it cannot distinguish even numbers from odd ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: To solve the task, I only need to compute (v1 - v0) / t without filtering numbers based on evenness.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To compute the sum of only even numbers, each input must be tested with a modulus operation (n % 2 == 0) to determine if it is even before adding it to the sum.
symptoms: No use of the modulus operator (%)
No if-statement that checks for evenness
Program computes a physics formula instead of filtering numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on a different problem (average acceleration) and lack of application of conditional logic to filter even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the input-processing loop, add an if (n % 2 == 0) condition to ensure that only even numbers are added to the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code includes no conditional statements or modulus operations at all, which are essential for checking even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Logic computes acceleration and prints it without any conditional checks for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator for the sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program does not declare or update a variable to accumulate the sum of even numbers, and instead prints a single computed acceleration value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The only value I need to compute and print is the acceleration derived from v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer accumulator variable that starts at 0 and is incremented by each even input value, then print the final sum with an appropriate message.
symptoms: No variable represents the sum of inputs
Output text reports average acceleration rather than sum of even numbers
No repeated addition of input values
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment with the problem requirements and lack of use of accumulator pattern for aggregation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0; variable, add to it only when an input is even, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by sum.
related_concepts: Initialization and update of variables in loops
Formatting output messages to match specifications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only computed variable is acceleration, and the printed message is about average acceleration rather than any sum.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Computation and output are for acceleration; there is no sum variable or message about the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements (Acceleration Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code designed to calculate acceleration, reading three double inputs (v0, v1, t), instead of the required program to read five integers and calculate the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a completely different assignment (calculating acceleration) and may believe this code fulfills the requirement for 'Sum of Even Numbers' or simply submitted the wrong file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be written to address the specific problem: read 5 integers, use a loop/sequential input, check for evenness, and accumulate the sum.
symptoms: Code structure is irrelevant to the task description
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Major error in problem identification or file submission.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description carefully and ensure the submitted code directly addresses the requirements of the 'Sum of Even Numbers' task. The current code is for calculating acceleration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements an acceleration calculation formula, which is entirely unrelated to summing even numbers. This is a clear case of non-fulfillment of the prompt.

evidence.note: The class name itself suggests a different purpose.
Reads incorrect variables (v0, v1, t, doubles) and performs an acceleration calculation, not the required sum of evens.
